details.purpose: For the capture and reporting of details of the VISA-A questionnaire, an index of the severity of Achilles tendinopathy.
details.use:
Use to record details of the VISA-A questionnaire, an index of the severity of Achilles tendinopathy.
This questionnaire is a patient-reported outcome measure (PROM) for foot and ankle surgery.
While openEHR archetypes are all freely available under an open license, the specific content of this archetype may be copyright protected. Any use of this archetype within implementations must be in compliance with the terms established by the copyright owners where a copyright exists.
details.misuse: Not to be used unless the terms of copyright have been observed (if a copyright exists).

items.items: VISA-A
VISA-A questionnaire: an index of the severity of Achilles tendinopathy.
Event Series
@ internal @
Point in time
A specific date and/or time which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
Tree
@ internal @
1 Minutes stiffness
Patient-reported estimation of how many minutes of stiffness in Achilles region is experienced when first getting up.
Questionnaire wording: For how many minutes do you have stiffness in the Achilles region on first getting up?
Zero minutes
The patient experiences zero minutes of stiffness in Achilles region when first getting up.
10 minutes
The patient experiences about 10 minutes of stiffness in Achilles region when first getting up.
20 minutes
The patient experiences about 20 minutes of stiffness in Achilles region when first getting up.
30 minutes
The patient experiences about 30 minutes of stiffness in Achilles region when first getting up.
100 minutes
The patient experiences about 100 minutes or more of stiffness in Achilles region when first getting up.
90 minutes
The patient experiences about 90 minutes of stiffness in Achilles region when first getting up.
80 minutes
The patient experiences about 80 minutes of stiffness in Achilles region when first getting up.
70 minutes
The patient experiences about 70 minutes of stiffness in Achilles region when first getting up.
60 minutes
The patient experiences 60 minutes of stiffness in Achilles region when first getting up.
50 minutes
The patient experiences about 50 minutes of stiffness in Achilles region when first getting up.
40 minutes
The patient experiences about 40 minutes of stiffness in Achilles region when first getting up.
2 Pain when stretching Achilles tendon

Patient-reported estimation of pain experienced, once warmed up for the day, when stretching Achilles tendon fully over the edge of a step (keeping knee straight), on a scale of 0 to 10, where 0 indicates strong severe pain and 10 indicates no pain.
Questionnaire wording: Once you are warmed up for the day, do you have pain when stretching the Achilles tendon fully over the edge of a step? (keeping knee straight)?
3 Pain when walking on flat ground

Patient-reported estimation of severity of pain experienced within 2 hours after walking on flat ground for 30 minutes, on a scale of 0 to 10, where 0 indicates strong severe pain or unable to walk for 30 minutes because of pain, and 10 indicates no pain.

Questionnaire wording: After walking on flat ground for 30 minutes, do you have pain within the next 2 hours? (If unable to walk on flat ground for 30 minutes because of pain, score 0 for this question).
4 Pain walking downstairs
Patient-reported estimation of severity of pain experienced when walking downstairs with a normal gait cycle, on a scale of 0 to 10 where 0 indicates strong severe pain and 10 indicates no pain.
Questionnaire wording: Do you have pain walking downstairs with a normal gait cycle?
5 Pain after heel raises

Patient-reported estimation of pain experienced during or immediately after doing 10 single leg heel raises from a flat surface, on a scale of 0 to 10 where 0 indicates strong severe pain and 10 indicates no pain.
Questionnaire wording: Do you have pain during or immediately after doing 10 (single leg) heel raises from a flat surface?
6 Single leg hops without pain
Patient-reported count of ability to do single leg hops without pain.
Questionnaire wording: How many single leg hops can you do without pain?
7 Sport or other physical activity
Patient-reported extent to which sport or other physical activity is currently being undertaken.
Questionnaire wording: Are you currently undertaking sport or other physical activity?
Not at all
The patient does not currently undertake sport or other physical activity.
Modified training and or modified competition
The patient is currently undertaking sport or other physical activity at a modified training and/or modified competition level.
Full training and or competion but not same level as before
The patient is currently undertaking sport or other physical activity at full training and/or competion level, but not the same level as when symptoms began.
Competing at same or higher level
The patient is currently competing in sport or other physical actity at the same or higher level as when symptoms began.
8a No pain, length of training
For patients experiencing no pain while undertaking Achilles tendon loading sports, length of time patient can train or practise.

Questionnaire wording: Please complete EITHER A, B or C in this question. â¢ If you have no pain while undertaking Achilles tendon loading sports please complete Q8a only. â¢ If you have pain while undertaking Achilles tendon loading sports but it does not stop you from completing the activity, please complete Q8b only. â¢ If you have pain that stops you from completing Achilles tendon loading sports, please complete Q8c only. A. If you have no pain while undertaking Achilles tendon loading sports, for how long can you train/practise?
Nil
Patient cannot train or practise.
1 to 10 minutes
Patient can train or practise for 1 to 10 minutes.
11 to 20 minutes
Patient can train or practise for 11 to 20 minutes.
21 to 30 minutes
Patient can train or practise for 21 to 30 minutes.
More than 30 minutes
Patient can train or practise for more than 30 minutes.
8b Some pain, length of training
For patients experiencing some pain while undertaking Achilles tendon loading sports, but pain does not stop them from completing training or practice, length of time patient can train or practise.
Questionnaire wording: B. If you have some pain while undertaking Achilles tendon loading sport, but it does not stop you from completing your training/practice for how long can you train/practise?
Nil
Patient cannot train or practise.
1 to 10 minutes
Patient can train or practise for 1 to 10 minutes.
11 to 20 minutes
Patient can train or practise for 11 to 20 minutes.
21 to 30 minutes
Patient can train or practise for 21 to 30 minutes.
More than 30 minutes
Patient can train or practise for more than 30 minutes.
8c Pain stopping completion, length of training
For patients experiencing pain while undertaking Achilles tendon loading sports which stops them from completing training or practice, length of time patient can train or practise.
Questionnaire wording: C. If you have pain that stops you from completing your training/practice in Achilles tendon loading sport, for how long can you train/practise?
Nil
Patient cannot train or practise.
1 to 10 minutes
Patient can train or practise for 1 to 10 minutes.
11 to 20 minutes
Patient can train or practise for 11 to 20 minutes.
21 to 30 minutes
Patient can train or practise for 21 to 30 minutes.
More than 30 minutes
Patient can train or practise for more than 30 minutes.
Total score
Total score from questions 1 to 8.
Total score as percentage
Total score from questions 1 to 8 as a percentage.
Tree
@ internal @
Confounding factors
Record any issues or factors that may impact on the score or interpretation.
ItemTree
@ internal @
Extension
Additional information required to capture local context or to align with other reference models/formalisms.
e.g. Local hospital departmental information or additional metadata to align with HL7 or CDISC equivalents.
